newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Foreign worker rule flummoxed by Vietnam officials.
newsitem.headline: Foreign worker rule flummoxed by Vietnam officials.

text.p: Vietnam's plans to tighten controls on overseas workers through a work permit system have hit delays because state notaries do not handle documents written in foreign languages, a government official said.

Phan Duc Binh of the Labour Ministry's legal department was quoted in state media on Tuesday as saying that an estimated 10,000 foreigners had been required to apply for work permits under rules first announced last October.

But he said the scheme was being delayed because local notarising officials refused to work with documents written in foreign languages, such as resumes, references and school certificates or university degrees.

"Enterprises using foreign labour have paid good attention to the rules. But this is a new issue for us so we need more time to implement it," he said, adding that the ministry was now asking foreign firms to translate the documents themselves.

Hanoi spelt out new rules in October last year requiring foreign workers to apply for a work permit, setting limits on the period they could stay in Vietnam, and compelling employers to train local staff to replace them.
The plan was originally expected to come into effect in March. Binh said the closure date for applications had now been extended to September 2.
